text:
Q: Which shortest path algorithm should I use for a weighted city road network in Python? A:

Q1) Which algorithm should be selected for this problem?

They're all feasible, but two are especially good fits. And both are available in popular pypi graph libraries.

Q2) Why [are these] algorithms suitable for finding the shortest path ... in a weighted road network?

Dijkstra is sort of the no-brainer, as it is simple, quite general, and has attractive running time. The original is quadratic in number of cities, and you could readily implement it. When relying on a library's implementation it would be reasonable to expect the 1984 Fredman & Tarjan variant. If we have C cities and R road segments, its complexity of O(C + R log R) is about the best one could hope for. Even an adversarially constructed map couldn't really bring an implementation to its knees with some pathological case.

A* is especially well suited to this graph, since it is a planar graph and from (lat, long)'s we can readily compute the crow flies distance from each city to Gulshan Iqbal. We call this an "admissable heuristic", and finding one is usually the sticking point in deciding whether A* is suitable for traversing a given graph. Sometimes a metric like "number of manufacturing steps still needed" to make a complete part will serve nicely as an admissable heuristic.

The original problem suggests we have a static graph, and asks that we print out a planned itinerary. In a variant problem we start in a Current location, we always have the same destination of Gulshan Iqbal, and we're told of zero or more road closures (no edge, or equivalently it's an infinite cost edge). We're asked for an adjacent node to journey to, and then we iterate with that as our Current location. In this setting A* is a big win over Dijkstra, since as the journey progresses it gets to mostly ignore locations in its rear-view mirror. Even in the static setting, A* wins if our road atlas is a giant graph of every city in the country, with most of them being irrelevant since visiting them would take us quite far from a crow flies path. A* simply never considers them.

Q3) How can the chosen algorithm be cleanly integrated into this existing class-based structure?

Your CityGraph class frankly hasn't implemented much of interest, yet. I wouldn't worry too much about sticking to what's in the OP.

Definitely import networkx and play with that. Define the graph, ask for a Dijkstra solution, then for an A* solution. The package is mature, it works well, you can't go wrong with it. It is pure python, so you may find it's not the fastest solution.

Once you have a little experience with that, if you want to produce your own Dijkstra implementation you'll be in a good position to see what the issues are and what the API should look like.

You might also import graphlib2. It's Rust on the inside, which could make a difference for large graphs. For small ones like we see in the OP, it likely won't matter.

Q: Table layout adjusting insides of components A:

So, this worked perfectly fine. Thanx again for that splendid idea!

I also built an extractor method that takes all the JComponents from already existing implementations and adds them into the GridBagLayout's container. Also works like a charm for simple UIs.

Q: Gradle cannot find KSP plugin for Room setup in new Android Studio project A:

It feels like Gradle simply can't find the KSP plugin online.

Correct. There never has been a version of that plugin named 2.0.21-1.0.1. You can see the official roster of releases, or at least ones for the past couple of years.

You need a version starting with 2.0.21- to match your Kotlin version. The most recent version matching that prefix is 2.0.21-1.0.28, released a bit over a year ago.

I would point out what to change in your code, but your code in your question does refer to the KSP plugin at all.

Q: Any good open-source OAuth2 nuget package? A:

what's the use-case here? I ask because you mention OAuth and then OpenID, which are related but OpenID has a specific purpose with an OAuth flow. Are you trying to allow your users to give authorization to other APIs? (and for what? just identity, or for only particular resources?) If this is only for your own server's authentication/authorization then you don't need an OAuth flow. You can just use the built-in identity stuff and keep everything same-domain.

Q: Firefox version 146 on Mac Catalina 10.15.7 slows my MacBook Pro to a crawl A:

Noted. Just thought I'd post this since it had to do with browser performance and it affected my ability to do any programming. I'll post this sort of stuff to Reddit in the future. I was going to delete it but decided to leave it in case someone else ran into the same problem. Just trying to help out my fellow man.
